snippet.textDisplay:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves. Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious. Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation. The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this. The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing. Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.
snippet.textOriginal:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves.  Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious.  Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation.  The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this.  The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing.  Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.

snippet.textDisplay:
First - this is a brilliant video. Thanks!!!.
Second, ... at the 5 minute mark, "the logistic curve levels out once you're approaching the total population size." This is ominous, since it suggests we're all "getting it" but if we're careful it will take longer. In real life, not everyone gets the virus. Do you have another video that explains what you add to the model to account for the fact that, in the end, we don't all catch the virus?
snippet.textOriginal:
First - this is a brilliant video. Thanks!!!. 
Second,  ... at the 5 minute mark, "the logistic curve levels out once you're approaching the total population size." This is ominous, since it suggests we're all "getting it" but if we're careful it will take longer. In real life, not everyone gets the virus. Do you have another video that explains what you add to the model to account for the fact that, in the end, we don't all catch the virus?

snippet.textDisplay:
Right now they are trying to lock some infected communities up in Italy. Since there will be at least some shuffeling with other communities (because Italy isn't a totalitarian state and cannot possibly lock communities consistently up) the mentioned clustering example in the video would apply. So what exactly is the difference between a perfect shuffle of the population and the clustering example? Does it really help to lock communities up or is it more or less anyway if we did that?
Nevertheless, I sufficiently worried about Covid 19 ;)

snippet.textDisplay:
Good job but you have to count that people heals after x days that they got ill.
So my model is
dc(t)/dt=k*c(t)-dc(t-x)/dt
Its a delay differential equation
It doesnt count immunized people.

snippet.textDisplay: Too soon to tell for sure, but it looks like the Inflection might be early March for cases outside of China.  If true, it puts the total case count out of China around 55k.  Adding the 80k for China (assuming they aren't fabricating their numbers), puts the total case count around 135k globally.  But if what appears to be an inflection, is just a wobble in the numbers, the numbers could go much higher.
snippet.textOriginal: Too soon to tell for sure, but it looks like the Inflection might be early March for cases outside of China.  If true, it puts the total case count out of China around 55k.  Adding the 80k for China (assuming they aren't fabricating their numbers), puts the total case count around 135k globally.  But if what appears to be an inflection, is just a wobble in the numbers, the numbers could go much higher.

snippet.textDisplay:
The data shows detected cases but if the incubation period is 5-6 days then true infections are a factor higher. I wonder by how much? Assuming, also, that infections aren't always detected, the actual infections are probably higher than the growth factor seen in those 5-6 days. As of 11 March, the UK and other countries are seeing a x10 increase in number of detections every 6.5 days, so it wouldn't be ridiculous to assume that actual cases are around 10x more prevalent.
Great video - I wish more people would recognise when a log scale is more appropriate, particularly the media. And sales departments.
snippet.textOriginal:

As of 11 March, the UK and other countries are seeing a x10 increase in number of detections every 6.5 days, so it wouldn't be ridiculous to assume that actual cases are around 10x more prevalent. 
Great video - I wish more people would recognise when a log scale is more appropriate, particularly the media. And sales departments.

snippet.textDisplay:
This makes mathematical sense, BUT a virus is not reproducing at a mathematical rate, it is reproducing at a human rate (which is random at best).
Factors to be taken into consideration are: Societal structure, political honesty in providing accurate data and, last but not least, infrastructure in containing a virus.
If you put one grain of rice on the first square of a chess board two in the second four on the third etc, you will always end up with 9223372036854775808 but (with great respect) if you apply logic to the expansion of a virus you might just as well try herding a group of cats... Cuger Brant: As Simple as ABC.
snippet.textOriginal:
This makes mathematical sense, BUT a virus is not reproducing at a mathematical rate, it is reproducing at a human rate (which is random at best). 
Factors to be taken into consideration are:  Societal structure, political honesty in providing accurate data and, last but not least, infrastructure in containing a virus. 
If you put one grain of rice on the first square of a chess board two in the second four on the third etc,  you will always end up with 9223372036854775808 but (with great respect) if you apply logic to the expansion of a virus you might just as well try herding a group of cats... Cuger Brant: As Simple as ABC.

snippet.textDisplay:
1.3^14 = 39
so if the growth factor is 1.3 and we have an incubation period of 14 days
=> the number of actually infected people is 39 times the number that we know today
snippet.textOriginal:
1.3^14 = 39
so if the growth factor is 1.3 and we have an incubation period of 14 days 
=> the number of actually infected people is 39 times the number that we know today

snippet.textDisplay:
Wrong

You've got that totally wrong.
Flu seasons are directly linked to UVB exposure and the individual persons production of Vitamin D; hence, the flu season in the Northern hemisphere and the flu in the Southern hemisphere.
As folks, Vitamin D level drops during late Fall / Autumn and Winter, their immune systems become weaker hence the flu seasons in the North and South.
To get your equations correct, you have to factor in the maximum and minimum UVB levels applicable to maximum change in sun-angle in relation to the Earth's surface. There is less UVB at the extreme Northern, Southern latitudes as-well as the Equator.
snippet.textOriginal:
Wrong

You've got that totally wrong.
Flu seasons are directly linked to UVB exposure and the individual persons production of Vitamin D; hence, the flu season in the Northern hemisphere and the flu in the Southern hemisphere.
As folks, Vitamin D level drops during late Fall / Autumn and Winter, their immune systems become weaker hence the flu seasons in the North and South.
To get your equations correct, you have to factor in the maximum and minimum UVB levels applicable to maximum change in sun-angle in relation to the Earth's surface. There is less UVB at the extreme Northern, Southern latitudes as-well as the Equator.

snippet.textDisplay: "If people are sufficiently worried, there’s much less to worry about, but if no one is worried, that’s when you should worry." The amount of new worried people is affected by the amount of worried people that already exist, therefore it most likely follows a logistic curve. Very funny.
snippet.textOriginal: "If people are sufficiently worried, there’s much less to worry about, but if no one is worried, that’s when you should worry." The amount of new worried people is affected by the amount of worried people that already exist, therefore it most likely follows a logistic curve. Very funny.

snippet.textDisplay: Why do these graphs always stop before showing exponential decay as seen in Wuhan, China? The virus grew very fast but it also disappeared very fast because of the actions taken by the population to protect themselves and perhaps the pool of vulnerable people getting infected. Apparently it wasn't just the second because the curve would have turned more gradually, WHO said.
snippet.textOriginal: Why do these graphs always stop before showing exponential decay as seen in Wuhan, China? The virus grew very fast but it also disappeared very fast because of the actions taken by the population to protect themselves and perhaps the pool of vulnerable people getting infected. Apparently it wasn't just the second because the curve would have turned more gradually, WHO said.
